p.s: The text at hand is an excerpt from Part Two, Chapterpart two, chapter 6, of the novel The Tortilla Curtain, written by T. C. Boyle and published in 1995 which deals with the collision of an illegal immigrant coupl and an American middle class couple who, despite their many differences and hateful feelings for one another, ultimately share the desire of living the American Dream.

The two worlds of the American couple, Delaney and Kyra Mossbacher, and the Mexican couple, América and Cándido Rincón, are for the first time confronted with eachother when Delaney hits Cándido with his car.
Afterwards, numerous incidents follow which change Delaney's attitude towards Mexican immigrants throughout the book.
At one point, his car is stolen and he believes it was a Mexican, whom he sees camping in the mountains.

Moreover, his wife Kyra ends up having an uncomfortable conversation with a Mexican who is based on her descriptino the same man, who Delaney sees in the mountain and is confronted with in this chapter.
The reader knows the man as José Navidad.
While Delaney's attitude towards Mexican immigrants is changing his Communitycommunity, Arroyo Blanco Estates, transforms into a gated community.
The excerpt at hand, shows Delaney at a turning point of his character development and is therefore important for the plot of the novel.
Delaney is confronted with having to choose a side, for or against building a wall around Arroyo Blanco and has a conversation with Todd Sweet, who tries to convince him of voting against the wall.
Delaney is uncertain and promises to call Todd Sweet, however without exchanging phone numbers before he leaves.
Delaney feels overwhelmed and alone with the decision when he spots a man crossing his neighbours', the Cherrystones', lawn.
As soon as he is able to identify the man as Mexican he is certain that the man is a criminal, trying to steal from the Cherrystones.
To his shock, he recognizes the man because he met him in the mountains and therefore links him to his stolen car.
When Delaney confronts the man with asking what he is doing on the Cherrystones' lawn he doesn't seem concerned and ignores Delaney.
The situation then escalates and Delaney threatens the man with calling the police.
The expectation of Delaney that the man is a criminal is then proven wrong when the man showsh im the fliersflyers he is delivering.

Left in astonishment, Delaney realizes his racist behaviour and reads the flierflyer which is about an upcoming meeting to decide on the construction of the wall, which brings him to the same topic from the beginning of the chapter.
